message: I'm in front of Mrs. Hudson's room.
The door is half open, as if it was expecting me, and light and warm air are spilling out.
Looks like Mrs. Hudson is still awake.
I gave the half-open door a light knock.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Who is it?
Is that you, Mr. Swift？

name: Jonathan
message: Yes, it's me.
May I come in?

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Please, come in.
It's in front of the lady's room.
The door is half open, but there's no sign of anyone inside.
I knocked on the door to the lady's room.

name: Jonathan
message: Mr. Hudson, are you here？
No answer.
Looks like the lady has gone out somewhere.
I decided to leave the lady’s room and go to the entrance hall.
This is Mrs. Hudson's room.
It's on the side of the Fish Scale Inn that doesn't get much sunlight and doesn't face the main street.
The wine bottle on the table-maybe it's one Mrs. Hudson likes to drink?
I've never heard that she drinks, though......
And looking at the label, it seems like it's some pretty expensive brandy, too.
Even if she does drink a little, would a lady really drink that kind of booze?
Usually it's just sherry or maybe some wine.
So then, does that mean there was a guy drinking in this room？
It looks like it was opened just recently, and more than half the contents are still left inside the bottle.
The room is as nondescript as ever, with nothing that gives any sense of Mrs. Hudson’s personality.
Judging by the fireplace being loaded up with plenty of firewood, it looks like the lady isn't planning to head to bed anytime soon.
Could it be that you were waiting here all along, expecting me to come to your room?
The lady is gazing right at me.
I feel like a husband who cheated or a kid who did something bad.
She's got a demure dress befitting a widow, and her attitude is so distant it's almost cold-hearted.
Whether it's because she doesn't like what Cordelia and I are doing, her expression is stiff and it's obvious she's not happy about a late-night visit.
What on earth can I do to get madam back in a good mood?
Honestly, I don't think there's any reason I have to placate Mrs. Hudson at all......
She doesn't look like she's having much fun, and she's just staring at me.
Looks like she's still in a bad mood.
Even though she's changed into her loungewear, the atmosphere isn't relaxed like usual, and tonight she seems even more distant than ever.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Cordelia's waiting, isn't she？
I have to go soon, or that girl will get lonely.
Guess the conversation got a bit too serious.
We should probably change the subject.

name: Jonathan
message: Forget about Cordelia-how about you, yourself？
How　long　are　you　planning　to　stay　in　Arkham?

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Even if you ask me how long...
There's no one who would take me away from here.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: I'll just have to lay my bones here.
There's nothing that can be done.

name: Jonathan
message: That's not true.
If you really wanted to, Hudson, couldn't you just go somewhere else anytime？

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: No.
I just can't do that......

name: Jonathan
message: I heard from Cordelia.
I heard your husband went missing.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: So there's still someone who remembers that, huh.
That's already old news.

name: Jonathan
message: Was your husband from Arkham？

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Yes, that's right.
I was the last person from the family that had run this Fish Scale Inn for generations.

name: Jonathan
message: You probably don't want to talk about this...
Why did your husband disappear?

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Isn't that something only the person themselves would know?
Now that we don't even know whether that person is alive or dead, there's no way for anyone to look into it anymore.

name: Jonathan
message: This might be unnecessary, but you look like you're tired.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: That's not true at all.

name: Jonathan
message: You really should leave Arkham no matter what.
This village is just too lonely a place for someone like you to live alone in.

name: Jonathan
message: I also heard the shopkeeper in front of the general store went missing too.
Cordelia's foster parents, too.

name: Jonathan
message: Even just from what I've heard, this many villagers have gone missing.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: It certainly is a strange story.
But, what about it?

name: Jonathan
message: Isn't it weird?
There must be some cause.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Really? I don't see it that way.
I don't know why, but there are just places like that.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: There are places where everyone seems to live long, and then there are other places where, for some reason, lots of people end up killing themselves.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: No one might be able to explain it, but there's definitely a place like that, for sure.

name: Jonathan
message: Do you really think that's all there is to it？

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: How else do you expect me to explain it？
I'm this kind of person, so I have no choice but to accept things as they are.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Swift, are you still bothered by what we talked about earlier？

name: Jonathan
message: What are you talking about?
I won't understand unless you say it clearly.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: You're heading out late at night.
Even if I'm pretty dense, I can at least tell where you're planning to go.

name: Jonathan
message: So, are you saying you're criticizing me for going to Cordelia's place late at night？

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: ......I don't really think it's very favorable.

name: Jonathan
message: But even for tonight, or before that, it was Cordelia who said she wanted me to come to her, you know？

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: I can accept that you two ended up in that kind of relationship, but every night...

name: Jonathan
message: It's not like I asked you to do that.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Even if that's true, it's because Cordelia has always been all alone.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: She was lonely because there wasn't anyone there to stay by her side.

name: Jonathan
message: You think I took advantage of that and forced something like that on you, don't you？

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: ......I wouldn't say that, though.

name: Jonathan
message: No, Hudson-san thinks that way.
You think I'm the kind of person who would do something like that.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Well, let me ask you then, what are you planning to do about Cordelia？

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: You don't actually think that leaving Arkham would be the end of it, do you?

name: Jonathan
message: I never said anything like that.
I'm thinking about it properly too, you know.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: So,　you're　planning　to　take　Cordelia　with　you　to　London.
Somehow, this has turned into a much more serious conversation than I expected.
I never thought I'd hear something like that straight from her mouth.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: I'm glad.
That was what I was worried about.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: If there's someone who can take her out of Arkham, that would be good for that girl.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: Please, just stop already.
You should go home.
I put my hand on the lady’s hands, which were folded on the Table.
The lady's hands are bony, and in contrast to her face and slender body, they look just like the hands of a working woman.

name: Mrs. Hudson
message: What are you doing？
Didn't Swift love Cordelia？
Entrance hall
Cafeteria
My room
